sections.heading: Plan Libraries
sections.text: As is standard, we take a library L for a target G as a rooted, ordered AND / OR graph, where each node is an AND node, an OR node, or a leaf. Leaves represent primitive tasks (actions), OR nodes are non-primitive tasks, and AND nodes are methods for decomposing non-primitive tasks. The children of an AND node n are AND nodes or leaves, while the children of an AND node are OR nodes or leaves. The children of an AND node n can be partially ordered; we write n ′ < n ′ to express that child n ′ must come from n before child n ′. The root of the library is a task (OR node) that represents the goal to be achieved. We allow libraries to be cyclic, and therefore CFGs are a special case in which the OR nodes for the non-terminals symbols in the AND grammar.

sections.text: From the descriptions found (Tambe et al. 1999) on planning hierarchies for controlling simulated RoboSoccer teams, we have defined a plan library for detecting the intentions of the opposing football team. sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text: We have shown that the recently formulated framework for planning recognition over STRIPS theories in (Ramirez and Geffner 2009) subsumes the planning recognition problem over libraries, as these can be summarized in STRIPS. We have also shown that recognition over standard libraries becomes planning problems that can be easily solved by modern planners, while recognition over more complex libraries, including CFGs, illustrates limitations of current planning heuristics and proposes improvements that can also be relevant to other planning problems (which need to be elaborated and demonstrated).

metadata.abstractText: In a recent paper, we have shown that Plan Recognition over STRIPS can be formulated and solved using Classical Planning heuristics and algorithms (Ramirez and Geffner 2009). In this work, we show that this formulation subsumes the standard formulation of Plan Recognition over libraries through a compilation of libraries into STRIPS theories. The libraries correspond to AND/OR graphs that may be cyclic and where children of AND nodes may be partially ordered. These libraries include Context-Free Grammars as a special case, where the Plan Recognition problem becomes a parsing with missing tokens problem. Plan Recognition over the standard libraries become Planning problems that can be easily solved by any modern planner, while recognition over more complex libraries, including Context–Free Grammars (CFGs), illustrate limitations of current Planning heuristics and suggest improvements that may be relevant in other Planning problems too.
